1118210507255758848.text: 17/ One drawback of the platform is that its automated market making mechanism makes it so that the larger a trade, the more price slippage occurs. The platform works well for smaller trades, but this makes it somewhat unusable for larger ones.

1118210506232299521.text: 16/ Worth nothing also that Uniswap is very gas efficient. It uses almost 10x less gas than Bancor in ETH to ERC20 trades (440,000 vs 46,000 gas), and can perform ERC20 to ERC20 trades more efficiently than 0x (113,000 vs 88,000 gas).

1118210505599082498.text: 15/  This goes into the liquidity reserves to ensure that the total reserve size in the exchange contract continually grows with each trade. The fees also serve as a payout to liquidity providers when they withdraw their holdings of the reserves.

1118210504915394560.text: 14/ When this happens, the provider's ETH and tokens are withdrawn at the current exchange rate (reserve ratio), rather than the ratio of their original investment. Uniswap itself does not take any commissions, but each txn by users is charged a 0.3% liquidity provider fee.

1118210270831218688.text: 13/Liquidity tokens are ERC20 tokens themselves and are specific to a single exchange pair (there is no uniform native token for the platform). Providers can burn their liquidity tokens at any time to withdraw their proportional shares of ETH and ERC20 tokens from the reserves.

1118210270164332547.text: 12/ When deposits occur, liquidity tokens (LTs) are created for the provider, so they can earn passive income from lending their coins to the reserves. LTs track the proportion of total reserves that each liquidity provider has contributed.

1118210269317087232.text: 11/ 1st liquidity provider to deposit into a contract sets its initial exchange rate by depositing an equivalent value of ETH and the respective token. If the ratio is off, arbitrage traders bring the prices to equilibrium (at the expense of the initial provider).

1118210268192964609.text: 10/ But how does this actually work? Liquidity is added to exchange contracts via liquidity providers depositing equivalent values of ETH and ERC20 tokens into them.

1118210054564515840.text:
9/ This pooled model smooths out the order book and allows for narrower spreads, requiring less active management on the part of market makers. Set it and forget it, FTW! (For more on the upsides of a pooled model, see @alexhevans's recent piece: 
https://www.placeholder.vc/blog/2019/4/9/defi-liquidity-models …)

1118210053360816128.text:
8/ For example, if an ERC20 token is being sold for ETH, the size of that token's
reserve in its exchange contract increases and the ETH reserve decreases. The mechanism shifts the reserve ratio to increase the price of the ETH relative to the token for future txns.

1118210051968311301.text: 7/ The constant product market maker formula calculates the exchange rate at which a trade will be executed based on the size of the transaction and the amount the incoming trade will shift this ratio.

1118210051196563457.text: 6/ Unlike other DEXs where traders buy/sell based on prices + volumes in an order book, Uniswap's exchange contracts act as automated market makers, where prices are set automatically using the constant product market maker mechanism, which keeps reserves in relative equilibrium.

1118210050399657987.text: 5/ Each of these contracts holds reserves of both ETH and the respective ERC20 token, creating an internal liquidity reserve. Trades are executed directly against these reserves. Exchange contracts are linked through the registry, allowing for direct token to token trades via ETH

1118209768957542402.text:
4/ What's novel about it? Most exchanges maintain an order book and facilitate
matches between buyers and sellers, but Uniswap doesn't. The protocol is composed of an ETH-ERC20 exchange smart contract for each ERC20 token on the platform.

1118209767988768768.text: 3/ Uniswap is open source, has no native token or platform fee and no incentives or special treatment awarded to early adopters or developers. Listing tokens is free and all smart contract functions are public.

1118209767237877761.text:
2/ First off, what is it? It's a protocol for automated exchange of ERC20
tokens on the Ethereum blockchain. It prioritizes decentralization and security and has eliminated rent extraction and censorship, enabling faster and more efficient exchange.

1110951008241250305.text: 4/ What’s the incentive system? In order to reward third party reporters to maintain accurate feeds, Polaris charges smart contracts a monthly subscription fee for the ability to read prices from the oracle. They’re rewarded w Oracle tokens that be redeemed for revenue.

1110949490217803777.text: 3/ So, what’s different here? Polaris makes attacks more costly by taking the median of price checkpoints over time. Attacks are not impossible but become much more expensive.

1110949138856710144.text: 2/ Why does this matter? Oracles are critical in crypto as an on-chain source of truth. The issue is that most current ones are either centralized, easy to manipulate, or lack incentives to keep feeds accurate over time.

1095372561955852295.text: 10) That’s all! If anyone has other tips would love to hear about them

1095372560181661698.text: 9) Use tech: I use @goodreads to keep track of books, Leio to keep track of time spent reading, and Highlighter to save passages. I’m a super tracker of all the things, so these make it more fun and improve retention for me.

1095372558256558081.text: 8)Library: the library is such an awesome and under appreciated resource. It eliminates cost from the equation and allows you to experiment more (if you don’t like the book, no pressure to finish cause you paid for it!)Just move on.

1095372556578799619.text: 7) Set ambitious goals: # of books per year, # of minutes per day etc. Even if you don’t hit them you’ll likely read much more than you would have otherwise.

1095372554842398720.text: 6) Interest: i only read things that genuinely interest me. Fortunately for me that’s a wide array, but everyone can find something they love to read. If you haven’t found it, keep looking!

1095372553105915910.text: 5) Block time: if you feel like you don’t have enough time, literally block it off on your calendar. Most of my best ideas have come from reading (often outside of my professional arena). Amazing how things transfer and you can recombine ideas in original ways.

1095372551629479941.text: 4) Style: I own a kindle but don’t love it. Tried to make myself like it for years (and consequently read less) but eventually gave up. I find my retention is way worse on Kindle. Find what works for you!

1095372546516635648.text: 3) Preparedness: I bought this handy little book light that I have in my bag all the time and use to read whenever it’s dark, especially in Ubers at night. It’s rechargeable and lasts forever. So nerdy but I love it!pic.twitter.com/cEEnFduanJ

1095372537666654208.text: 2) Variety: I keep lots of books on hand, and am generally reading 2-4 at a time, of different genres. Alternating allows me to pick whatever suits my mood at the moment (sometimes I’m too tired for non fiction but fiction is perfect, etc).

1095372535997321216.text: 1) Availability: I always, always have a book on me. Down time becomes time to read rather than mindlessly browsing Instagram. Added plus: any delay is much less of a nuisance since I can make productive use of time.

1057052019335225344.text: 7/ Spend a couple of days or weeks really going into something and you will both understand and retain it 10x better. This moves it from something that you "learned" (and could forget) to something that you "know" –– in the same way you know your childhood memories (permanent).

1057052018492157952.text: 6/ I find that concentrated reading about one topic is way more effective for deep understanding and long-term memory gelling than flitting between topics (even if total amount of time is equal in both cases) .

1057052017531609088.text: 5/ Important: don't worry that you don't understand everything. Just keep reading. Brains are magical in that they will later fish out information that you didn't even know you had archived, and all of a sudden the full picture starts to form.

1057052016755695616.text: 4/ Look for articles of increasing complexity. If you need to understand a different concept to move fwd (i.e. need to learn what a Pedersen Commitment is in order to grasp the mechanics of a protocol) open a new tab and do a bit of reading, but don't get stuck.

1057052015908478977.text: 3/ At the beginning, look for basic articles –– Wikipedia or high-level press. You want to create a very rough sketch in your mind about the topic at hand. There will be lots of holes and fuzzy areas, but you can fill those in later.

1029078623976796160.text: 9/ Investors have many different reasons for why they might choose to invest in a company. Especially if you don’t know them personally and haven’t discussed their rationale, it’s very dangerous to play follow-the-leader. Do your own homework!

1029078622882029568.text: 8/ You really can’t draw too many conclusions about why someone made an investment unless you have a comprehensive understanding of their portfolio.

1029078622202515456.text: 7/ But from an outside perspective, someone seeing a headline “XYZ investor invests in layer-two protocol” who doesn’t know this investor is a bitcoin whale might follow XYZ into that investment, without holding any bitcoin, and end up with a very different outcome.

1029078621422415872.text: 6/ And sometimes, they’re portfolio-driven:if you are a BTC whale and you think a layer-two scalability solution could make the value of your BTC increase tenfold, it makes sense to invest in the company building the solution whether or not you expect any return from the company.

1029078620524826624.text: 5/ Sometimes they’re learning-driven: they may think the company will fail, but want to use the investment to learn more about a particular industry (and compared to college these days, that $50K seems like cheap tuition).

1029078619669155841.text: 4/ Sometimes they’re curiosity-driven: the investor might think the company has an extremely low likelihood of succeeding, but find the entrepreneur interesting enough to want to be able to call them up occasionally, which is easier when you’re an investor in the company.

1029078618796740611.text: 3/ Sometimes they’re relationship-driven: if your personal net worth is a few billion, it may literally be easier for you to write a $50K check into a company than it is to deal with saying no. A token investment gets you out of the awkwardness of declining.

1029078617957969920.text: 2/ Different investors, particularly those writing personal checks, have a whole slew of reasons for which they might invest, many of which are not strictly tied to expected financial upside.

1023976202048954370.text: 1/ My views on the future number of tokens are evolving. A few thoughts:

1023781918498672641.text: I’m tired of the “I’m so busy” narrative. We need to stop giving out metaphorical busy gold stars. Having a full schedule doesn’t mean you’re accomplishing more; the best work often happens during unstructured time.

1023397326730092544.text: I absolutely love the feeling of healthy exhaustion after a long run.pic.twitter.com/OH2RBOh5ps

1022610923809193984.text: 13/ I’m increasingly convinced that in crypto, the coins with the strongest communities are going to be the winners. As @bendavenport put it, missionaries always trump mercenaries. /fin

1022610921808515072.text: 12/ Any piece of technology that can create a movement - and a group of people who MUST HAVE IT - is basically unstoppable.

1022610920155959296.text: 11/ In my mind, this maps to HODLers - they’re holding for the eventual financial upside, but also due to a strong ideological belief.

1022610918503378944.text: 10/ The gamers didn’t have to pay - they chose to, despite it not being immediately financially rational to do so. Amazingly, they donated millions of dollars in this fashion.

1022610916649521154.text: 9/ The early game creators also pioneered the concept of shareware, where games were distributed for free, and paid for on a voluntary, donation basis by the gamers.

1022610912987865088.text: 8/ But the most important similarity between today’s crypto and 1990s gaming worlds is the religious fervor of both communities.

1022610911289196544.text: 7/ The crypto parallel is scalability: as CryptoKitties demonstrated, right now most dApps are limited by speed and throughout issues on the underlying chains. I believe that like PCs eventually got up to speed, we will figure out how to scale blockchains as well.

1022610909544337408.text: 6/ Game developers were also limited not by the limits of their creativity, but by the boundaries of the technology. PCs were initially too slow to run any good games - and only eventually did some of the best technical minds come up with solutions.

1022610907887620098.text: 5/ This is so clearly the phase we are still in for cryptocurrencies and dApps. Most require a decent base of technical knowledge, a willingness to experiment, and a tolerance for poor UX.

1022610906184802304.text: 4/ It was a huge hassle to play games in the early days - initially they had to be typed in by hand, they were slow, computers weren’t readily available, etc etc. And yet, gamers couldn’t get enough of them.

1022610903684894721.text: 3/ The parallel here is the narrative of crypto being used for drug dealing and nefarious activity - in the early days bitcoin was the target, and now it has become privacy coins. Trying to ban these things rarely (if ever) works.

1022610902074314754.text: 2/ In the early days, the violence in video games caused a backlash from conservatives who wanted to ban them. One case went all the way to the Supreme Court, but was ultimately dismissed.

1022610894813974528.text: 1/ I inhaled Masters of Doom over the last couple evenings. Aside from being a super engaging read, it reminded me of a lot of similarities between the early gaming & crypto communities.https://www.amazon.com/Masters-Doom-Created-Transformed-Culture/dp/0812972155 …

1022191185241223170.text:
